content: The Older Americans Act (OAA), enacted in 1965, provides social services and programs for individuals aged 60 and older. Services include congregate and home-delivered nutrition, caregiver support, community service employment, long-term care ombudsman program, and abuse prevention. All programs, except for Community Service Employment for Older Americans, are administered by the Administration on Aging. The Older Americans Act (OAA) provides various services for individuals aged 60 and older, including nutrition services, caregiver support, community service employment, long-term care ombudsman program, and abuse prevention. Most programs are administered by the Administration on Aging, except for Community Service Employment for Older Americans. Funding for different OAA titles comes from annual HHS appropriations. The Older Americans Act (OAA) is administered by the Administration on Aging (AOA) in the Administration for Community Living (ACL) within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). Title V is administered by the Department of Labor's (DOL's) Employment and Training Administration. OAA has been reauthorized and amended by Congress multiple times, with the last reauthorization occurring in 2006. OAA Title V funding is provided in the annual DOL appropriations, while Title I does not authorize appropriations. Congress has reauthorized and amended the OAA multiple times, with the last reauthorization in 2006. Funding for OAA-authorized programs has continued even after the authorizations expired in FY2011. The Older Americans Act Amendments of 2006 (P.L. 109-365) authorized appropriations through FY2011. Despite the expiration of authorizations, Congress has continued to fund OAA programs. This report discusses FY2015 funding, including a breakdown of funding for each program, funding history since FY2001, legislative activity, and funding decisions for selected programs. Aging and Disability Resource Centers aim to provide a single entry point for information on public and private long-term services and supports. Aging and Disability Resource Centers (ADRCs) offer a range of public and private long-term services and supports to consumers, including counseling on LTSS options, access to programs like Medicaid, and discharge planning services. There are over 500 ADRC sites nationwide, with 5.2 million client contacts in FY2012. ADRCs received $10 million in funding from FY2010 to FY2014. ADRCs provide services to help individuals stay at home after hospitalization or rehabilitation. There are over 500 ADRC sites nationwide, with 5.2 million client contacts in FY2012. ADRCs received $10 million in funding from FY2010 to FY2014, with additional funding proposed in the President's FY2015 budget. The ADRCs received $10 million in mandatory funding under the ACA, with additional discretionary funding authorized under OAA Title II. The President's FY2015 budget proposed no discretionary funding for ADRCs but suggested $20 million each year for five years in renewed mandatory funding. A total of $100 million has been provided since 2003 by AOA and CMS to develop ADRC services. Additional funding could help ADRC programs assist states in meeting requirements for an enhanced federal matching rate under Medicaid.
